task.title: Configure DNS
task.shortdesc: provides a DNS service that maps service names, bucket names, and more to IP addresses. This section details how to configure the DNS service.

context.note: administration tools are designed to work with DNS-enabled clouds, so configuring this service is highly recommended. The remainder of this guide is written with the assumption that your cloud is DNS-enabled.
context.p: The DNS service will automatically try to bind to port 53. If port 53 cannot be used, DNS will be disabled. Typically, other system services like dnsmasq are configured to run on port 53. To use the DNS service, you must disable these services.
Before using the DNS service, configure the DNS subdomain name that you want to handle using the steps that follow.

info.p: When this option is enabled, public and private DNS entries are created for each launched instance in . This also enables virtual hosting for Walrus. Buckets created in Walrus can be accessed as hosts. For example, the bucket mybucket is accessible as mybucket.objectstorage.mycloud.example.com.
Instance IP addresses will be mapped as euca-A-B-C-D.eucalyptus.mycloud.example.com, where A-B-C-D is the IP address (or addresses) assigned to your instance.

info.p: When this value is modified, the public and private DNS names reported for each instance will contain the specified custom DNS subdomain name, instead of the default value, which is eucalyptus. For example, if this value is set to foobar, the instance DNS names will appear as euca-A-B-C-D.foobar.mycloud.example.com.

context.p: DNS delegation allows you to forward DNS traffic for the subdomain to the CLC host. This host acts as a name server. This allows interruption-free access to cloud services in the event of a failure. The CLC host is capable of mapping cloud host names to IP addresses of the CLC and UFS / OSG hosts.

For example, if the IP address of the CLC is 192.168.5.1, and the IP address of Walrus is 192.168.6.1, the host compute.mycloud.example.com will resolve to 192.168.5.1 and objectstorage.mycloud.example.com will resolve to 192.168.6.1.

context.p: Set up your master DNS server to delegate the subdomain to the UFS servers, which act as name servers.
The following example shows how the Linux name server bind is set up to delegate the subdomain.

step.cmd: Open /etc/named.conf and set up the example.com zone. For example, your /etc/named.conf may look like the following:
Create /etc/bind/db.example.com if it does not exist. If your master DNS is already set up for example.com, you will need to add a name server entry for UFS machine hosts. For example:

info.codeblock:
$ORIGIN example.com. $TTL 604800
@ IN SOA ns1 admin.example.com 1 604800 86400 2419200 604800 NS ns1 ns1 A MASTER.DNS.SERVER_IP ufs1 A UFS1_IP mycloud NS ufs1
info.p: After this, you will be able to resolve your instances' public DNS names such as euca-A-B-C-D.eucalyptus.mycloud.example.com.

step.cmd: Restart the bind nameserver service named restart.

Verify your setup by pointing /etc/resolv.conf on your client to your primary DNS server and attempt to resolve compute.example.com using ping or nslookup. It should return the IP address of a UFS server.

context.p: Recursive lookups and split-horizon DNS are available in .

step.cmd: To enable any of the DNS resolvers, set dns.enabled to true.
To enable the recursive DNS resolver, set dns.recursive.enabled to true.
To enable split-horizon DNS resolution for internal instance public DNS name queries, set dns.split_horizon.enabled to true.
